description.narrative: Algerian youth- who represent roughly 60 percent of the country’s population--are increasingly disenchanted with the status quo. In addition to political disillusionment among youth and the citizenry at large, the regime now faces substantial economic and social obstacles. These economic concerns are particularly acute for young Algerians, who are unemployed at a rate triple the national average of 10 percent. Roughly 25 percent of Algerian youth currently express a desire to leave the country, reflecting widespread frustration among this population group. A more meaningful integration of youth voices into local-level governance processes would help in addressing the trust gap that exists and disenfranchisement that can contribute to a push toward greater apathy, antagonism or more extremist views and actions if left unaddressed by mainstream political institutions and leaders. By developing a greater stake in and commitment to implementing meaningful changes in their local communities, youth would be less likely to resort to violence as an outlet for voicing their demands. Moreover, if youth had greater opportunity to participate in and influence political processes that impact their lives, they would be more likely to be invested in staying within their communities and contributing to local progress rather than looking to emigrate abroad. This program focuses on enhancing youth civic engagement in local and national level political processes. Through strengthening their capacity for effective civic participation, graduates of this program would be better-equipped to augment youth inclusion in the Algerian political system. Specifically, NDI would conduct a three-part leadership academy for youth, equipping participants, who will mainly be drawn from the south, with the skills to organize participatory needs assessments within their communities and implement advocacy campaigns based on the findings of these assessments. NDI would provide individual guidance to each program participant as they implement their advocacy campaigns, and would organize a training-of-trainers (TOT) workshop to assist youth participants in effectively transferring these new skills to their peers. NDI also would select and provide ongoing coaching to a program steering committee, or representative group of academy participants, who would liaise with national-level stakeholders such as the High Youth C ouncil and issue a summary report on the overall findings of academy participant-led work, including priority issues and common barriers to--and opportunities for--youth-led advocacy efforts.
